title: 'Between Two Fires' Review: Doing a Deal With the Devil
summary: Under Putin the state share of the economy has grown to more than 60%. Russians have to play the government's game to get what they want.. Like the winter snows on the Russian steppe, books on Vladimir Putin and his country keep coming and coming. The worst of these studies claim to possess some master key that unlocks the secret, guiding logic at the heart of Putin's Russia. The best, on the other hand, show that there never has been any single key and that the politics of the last two decades should be seen as a series of fits and starts, of improvisations characterized by short-term goals devoid of any underlying grand vision. Two of the finest recent works to make the point are Samuel A. Greene and Graeme B. Robertson's "Putin v. the People" and Robert Service's "Kremlin Winter." And now we can add a third-Joshua Yaffa's "Between Two Fires," a fascinating and nuanced account that illuminates the myriad conflicting and often contradictory forces that have shaped the Russia of today.

title: The Plot to Politicize Banking
summary: Liberal lawmakers and activists want banks to lend to favored groups and deny the 'undesirables.'. To resist President Trump's campaign of economic reform and deregulation, his critics usually attempt to portray long-overdue, common-sense policies as assaults on the poor. A good example is the controversy regarding the Community Reinvestment Act, or CRA, which requires banks to meet the "credit needs" of their "entire community, including low- and moderate-income neighborhoods, consistent with the safe and sound operation of such institutions." The media howled at a plan to rein in abuses of the law-despite its role in fueling the subprime crisis-setting off a fight among regulators.

title: A Selective Opponent of 'Settlers'
summary: Human Rights Watch's Sara Leah Whitson has one standard for Israel, another for Armenia.. Hypocritical attacks on Israel are common, but Sarah Leah Whitson takes them to a new level. As Middle East and North Africa director of Human Rights Watch, she is one of the sharpest critics of the Jewish state's presence in the West Bank, promoting boycotts and international prosecution for the supposed crimes of occupation and settlement. Yet elsewhere Ms. Whitson strongly supports settlements in occupied territories-suggesting that she and her colleagues don't take their own legal claims against Israel seriously.

title: Cory Booker Goes Down Fighting
summary: The former Newark mayor refused to bow to teachers unions.. You've got to hand it to Sen. Cory Booker. The former mayor of Newark, N.J., refused to be bullied when it comes to charter schools. That earned him the ire of teachers unions and contributed to the failure of his presidential candidacy. Anti-school-choice lobbyists were never going to forgive him for saying at the 2008 Democratic National Convention that they had "tarred and feathered" him for supporting charters.

summary: Activists celebrate the end of moderation in the Democratic field.. Bernie Sanders lost the 2016 Democratic presidential nomination to Hillary Clinton. title: Ghosn, Nissan and Japan's Justice System
summary: Your editorials "Ghosn, Baby, Ghosn" (Jan. 9) and "The Carlos Ghosn Experience" (Jan. 2) don't accurately reflect the Japanese criminal justice system.. Your editorials "Ghosn, Baby, Ghosn" (Jan. 9) and "The Carlos Ghosn Experience" (Jan. 2) don't accurately reflect the Japanese criminal justice system. In Japan, unlike in some other democracies, arrests require permission of judges except for cases such as arresting someone while committing a crime. Only significant cases with sufficient evidence are subject to indictment, since becoming a party to a criminal trial imposes a burden on a suspect; Japan's indictment ratio is only 37%-"99.3%" is the percentage of convictions divided by the number of indictments, not the criminals. As such, the conviction rate is high.

title: Former Pope Benedict Distances Self From Debate on Married Priests
summary: The issue has raised questions within the Catholic Church over the former pope's role in the Vatican. title: Society Needs Good Water, Public or Private
summary: We need to improve our water services, but we need to do it under the protection of public ownership.. Regarding Seth M. Siegel's "Warren Has a Plan for Your Drinking Water-but It's Risky" (op-ed, Jan. 3): Regardless of where you fall on the political spectrum, water privatization isn't in your best interest as a consumer. The U.S. is facing a water-affordability crisis, and if we hand over water services to private companies, as Mr. Siegel encourages, that crisis will worsen. On average, private water utilities charge typical households 59% more than local governments charge, largely because private financing is significantly more expensive than government borrowing on the municipal-bond market.

title: Australia's Exported Coal Fuels China's CO2 Deluge

title: 'Veep' Writer Launches Into an 'Absurd' Future and a Dickensian Past
summary: Armando Iannucci discusses his HBO science-fiction comedy 'Avenue 5' debuting Sunday, and a later feature film, 'The Personal History of David Copperfield'. Writer Armando Iannucci's latest projects-a comedy series set in space called "Avenue 5" and a movie of Charles Dickens' "David Copperfield"-take him back to his roots in two fields unlikely to mix: sketch comedy and literary studies. Before writing the political satires he is known for, including the television series "Veep," he helped create Alan Partridge, Steve Coogan's character of a self-satisfied TV host. Before that Mr. Iannucci was writing a dissertation at Oxford University about religious language in "Paradise Lost." He dropped out when he realized that you can sing the opening lines of "Paradise Lost" to the tune of the "Flintstones" theme song. "That's the point where I thought, OK, I'm not taking this seriously," he says. "You can't unhear that."

title: Companies Boost Capabilities Through Mergers and Acquisitions
summary: Businesses added complementary services in nearly 60% of deals in 2019. Companies increasingly are using acquisitions to buy new technological skills as a way of boosting their top-line growth, according to a report by Bain & Co.

title: In a Year of Trade War, U.S. Deficit With China Shrank
summary: But China still exports more to the U.S. than the other way around. BEIJING-President Trump's trade war with Beijing reduced the U.S.'s trade deficit with China last year, although Chinese manufacturers still export far more to the U.S. than vice versa.

title: Trump's Tax on Champagne Will Cost U.S. Consumers
summary: Tariffs on $2.4 billion of French wine and luxury imports could backfire in the battle over digital taxes. As Sino-American trade relations have improved in recent weeks, President Trump has turned up the heat on his European allies. But it is U.S. businesses and consumers that could end up burned.

title: Yuan Rallies After U.S. Drops Currency-Manipulator Label
summary: Currency hits its strongest level since July in offshore trading. China's currency strengthened to its strongest level since July in offshore trading, after the U.S. removed the country from a list of trading partners it considers currency manipulators, days before the likely signing of a trade deal.

title: Hong Kong's Index Tweak Would Raise Exposure to China Even More
summary: Allowing companies with different classes of shares, secondary listings onto the Hang Seng Index would undoubtedly make the benchmark more mainland-heavy. Hong Kong's benchmark stock index has become increasingly exposed to China in recent years. A consultation launched Monday could make that even more apparent.

title: LSU Wins a Homecoming Championship, Among Friends
summary: A home state crowd at the Superdome celebrates a historic victory over Clemson in New Orleans. New Orleans

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription.

title: 9/11 Responders Have Higher Rates of Leukemia, Study Shows
summary: The study is the first to show an increase in incidence of the blood cancer. Researchers found an elevated incidence of leukemia in first responders and other workers at the World Trade Center site after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks compared with the general population.

title: Senators Urge $1 Billion Plan to Loosen China's Grip on 5G
summary: Bipartisan bill would subsidize tech firms in their efforts to compete with Beijing-backed Huawei. A bipartisan group of U.S. senators, alarmed by the rise of Chinese electronics supplier Huawei Technologies Co., wants Washington to subsidize firms that could counter China's 5G advances.

title: McClatchy Freezes Some Pension Benefits as Publisher Seeks Bailout
summary: Second-largest U.S. newspaper publisher halts payments to some recipients of retirement plan targeted for possible government takeover. McClatchy Co. , the second-largest newspaper publisher in the U.S. by circulation, has frozen pension payments to some former executives and enlisted the services of a bankruptcy-administration firm as it seeks a government takeover of its retirement plan, the company's chief financial officer said.

title: Trump Administration Plans to Shift Additional $7.2 Billion for Border Wall
summary: Pentagon funds would come from two primary pots: for military construction and counternarcotics efforts. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration is planning to shift an additional $7.2 billion out of military coffers for border-wall construction, according to two people familiar with the plans.

title: Warren, Sanders Clash Ahead of Democratic Debate
summary: Elizabeth Warren says she and Bernie Sanders disagreed on whether a woman could win the White House; Mr. Sanders denies her account. WASHINGTON-Sen. Elizabeth Warren said that Sen. Bernie Sanders, one of her rivals for the Democratic presidential nomination, told her during a private 2018 meeting that a woman couldn't win the U.S. presidency-a statement Mr. Sanders denies.

title: America Drank Less Wine for First Time in 25 Years
summary: Millennials opted for other beverages and baby boomers pulled back. America's love affair with wine is waning.

title: Picking Winners in China's Car Market Crash
summary: Some brands are still doing well in the world's largest car market. Investors shouldn't accept excuses from the likes of GM and Ford.. The world's largest car market continues to skid. Investors should focus on those brands that have managed to steer clear of the wreck.

title: Trump Administration Makes Supreme Court Appeal on Immigration Plan
summary: The administration wants to implement a plan to make it easier for the government to deny immigrants residency. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration filed an emergency appeal Monday that asks the Supreme Court for permission to implement rules that would make it easier for the government to deny immigrants residency or admission to the U.S. because they use public-assistance programs or might use them in the future.

title: Judge Fines Wisconsin Board for Not Removing Voters From Rolls
summary: Contempt finding follows lawsuit by conservative group to force state to remove voters who hadn't verified their home addresses. A Wisconsin judge held the state elections board in contempt for not following his order to remove thousands of people from voter rolls.

title: Man Accused in New York Hanukkah Stabbing Pleads Not Guilty
summary: Grafton E. Thomas faces federal hate-crime charges in machete attack at rabbi's home. The man accused of stabbing five people during a Hanukkah celebration in Monsey, N.Y., pleaded not guilty Monday to federal hate-crime charges.

title: Target and Lowe's Tech Execs Credit Talent, Culture for Insourcing Success
summary: Companies need to develop those technologies core to their processes, says Lowe's CIO Seemantini Godbole. NEW YORK-Large retailers are finding that the right talent and the right company culture are critical to success as they bring more software development in-house to stay competitive.

title: Lawmakers Tangle Over Calling Witnesses in Impeachment Trial
summary: Democrats seeking to add new witnesses say that they were blocked from calling several during House probe. WASHINGTON-Top lawmakers continued to trade barbs over introducing new witnesses in the coming impeachment trial of President Trump, as House Democrats prepared to send the case to the Senate.

title: New Jersey Legislature Passes Flavored-Vape Ban
summary: Measures are part of growing movement to curtail youth vaping. New Jersey lawmakers approved a legislative package strengthening regulations on e-cigarettes, including a ban on flavored-vaping products, in a growing campaign to fight tobacco use among young people.

title: Visa to Pay $5.3 Billion for Fintech Startup Plaid
summary: Plaid will help expand its access to financial-technology firms while accelerating its movement outside of cards, Visa CEO says. Visa Inc. said Monday it would buy Plaid Inc. for $5.3 billion, as part of an effort by the card giant to tap into consumers' growing use of financial-technology apps and noncard payments.

title: NYPD Faces Probe Over Policing of Subway Fare Evasion
summary: Attorney general launches investigation to determine whether people of color are illegally targeted. New York state Attorney General Letitia James has launched an investigation into whether the New York Police Department has been illegally targeting people of color in its enforcement of fare-evasion laws in the New York City subway, her office said in a statement Monday.

title: Barr Tightens Approvals of Probes of Presidential Campaigns
summary: Move follows criticism about handling of a counterintelligence probe into Trump-Russia links. WASHINGTON-Future investigations involving a U.S. presidential candidate or campaign will have to be approved by the leaders of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Justice Department, Attorney General William Barr said.
